FAA regulations do not permit children two years or older to travel as lap infants.<ref>https://www.faa.gov/travelers/fly_children/</ref> The passenger appealed to the Flight Attendant but the FA was dismissive, shrugged her shoulders and said the flight was full.<ref>https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation/2017/07/06/mom-has-carry-boy-flight-after-united-takes-his-seat-and-resells/454585001/</ref><ref>https://www.hindustantimes.com/world-news/woman-forced-to-carry-child-on-lap-sues-us-airlines/story-kcMQnqohoJ1wOVl0OW88WM.html</ref><ref>https://abcnews.go.com/US/united-airlines-toddlers-seat-forces-mom-hold-flight/story?id=48463404</ref><ref>https://liveandletsfly.boardingarea.com/2017/07/06/united-airlines-child-seat/</ref> The passenger was afraid to push the issue because of what happened to Dr. Dao.<ref>https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation/2017/07/06/mom-has-carry-boy-flight-after-united-takes-his-seat-and-resells/454585001/</ref><ref>https://www.hindustantimes.com/world-news/woman-forced-to-carry-child-on-lap-sues-us-airlines/story-kcMQnqohoJ1wOVl0OW88WM.html</ref><ref>https://abcnews.go.com/US/united-airlines-toddlers-seat-forces-mom-hold-flight/story?id=48463404</ref><ref>https://liveandletsfly.boardingarea.com/2017/07/06/united-airlines-child-seat/</ref>When she flew back to Hawaii, United Airlines gave her a lei.<ref>https://www.hindustantimes.com/world-news/woman-forced-to-carry-child-on-lap-sues-us-airlines/story-kcMQnqohoJ1wOVl0OW88WM.html</ref>
A family on a Delta Airlines flight was removed from the aircraft and threatened with jail time and loss of custody of their children by Delta Airlines staff for not giving up a seat that they had purchased for their teenage son who was not flying on the flight. Delta refused to provide any compensation or lodging for the family.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nbcnews.com/news/us-news/california-family-kicked-delta-flight-threatened-jail-refusing-give-toddler-n755141|title=Family kicked off flight, threatened with jail, for refusing to give up child's seat|publisher=|access-date=January 25, 2018}}</ref>
==See also== * [[List of air rage incidents]] * "[[United Breaks Guitars]]", song about the singer's struggle with the airline to get compensation for an instrument damaged during transit on a United flight

{{Use mdy dates|date=February 2011}} {{Infobox person | birth_name = William Henry Trotter Bush | birth_date = {{Birth date |1938|07|14|mf=yes}} | birth_place = [[Greenwich, Connecticut]] | death_date = {{Death date and age |2018|02|27|1938|07|14|}} | death_place = [[West Palm Beach, Florida]] | party = [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] | parents = [[Prescott Bush]]
Dorothy Walker Bush | education = [[Hotchkiss School]] (1956)
[[Yale University]] (B.A. 1960) | relatives = See [[Bush family]] }} '''William Henry Trotter "Bucky" Bush''', [[Order of Saint John (chartered 1888)|CStJ]] (July 14, 1938 – February 27, 2018) was an American businessman. He was the youngest son of [[Prescott Bush|Prescott Sheldon Bush]] and Dorothy Walker Bush, the youngest brother of former President [[George H. W. Bush]], and an uncle of former President [[George W. Bush]]. ==Biography== Born in [[Greenwich, Connecticut]], he graduated from the [[Hotchkiss School]], [[Lakeville, Connecticut]] in 1956,{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1991/06/23/nyregion/franklin-s-greatest-hits-at-early-music-festival.html|title=Franklin's Greatest Hits At Early Music Festival|first=Valerie|last=Cruice|publisher=''[[The New York Times]]''|date=June 23, 1991|access-date=March 8, 2015}}*a"Mr. Bush, who grew up in Greenwich and graduated from the Hotchkiss School and Yale University, is a bit of a musician himself, he said recently." — ¶ 16 and earned a B.A. from [[Yale University]] in 1960, where he became a brother of the [[Psi Upsilon]] fraternity. In 2009, he was appointed a Commander Brother of the [[Order of Saint John (chartered 1888)|Most Venerable Order of the Hospital of Saint John of Jerusalem]] by [[Elizabeth II|HM Queen Elizabeth II]].https://www.thegazette.co.uk/notice/L-59148-888305 Bush lived in [[St. Louis]], [[Missouri]], also the home of his late grandfather [[George Herbert Walker]]. He died on February 27, 2018, in [[West Palm Beach, Florida|West Palm Beach]], [[Florida]].https://www.bizjournals.com/stlouis/news/2018/02/28/william-bucky-bush-chairman-of-bush-odonnell-dies.htmlhttps://www.bizjournals.com/stlouis/news/2018/02/28/william-bucky-bush-chairman-of-bush-odonnell-dies.html ==Business== Bush worked in banking and [[venture capital]], and sat on a number of corporate boards. He founded Bush O'Donnell & Co. in 1986 and remained CEO of that firm until his death. He worked on the election campaigns of George H. W., George W., and [[Jeb Bush]], primarily as a fundraiser. A former president of and director of the St. Louis-based [[Boatmen's Bancshares]] from 1978 to 1986, Bush was active in various St. Louis civic functions: he was chairman of the Board of Trustees of [[Saint Louis University]] from 1985 to 1992, chairman of the [[Missouri Botanical Garden]] from 1991 to 1993 and president of the [[The Muny|Municipal Opera Association]] from 2005 to 2006.[http://www.bushodonnell.com/capitalpartners/whtbush.htm William H.T. (Bucky) Bush – bushodonnell.com – Retrieved January 28, 2008] He was also a director of [http://www.maritz.com/ Maritz, Inc], and served on the Blue Cross Blue Shield of Missouri board of directors from 1989 to 1994.Forbes. https://www.forbes.com/profile/william-bush/ On May 18, 2010, Bush was taken to [[Indiana University Health Methodist Hospital|Methodist Hospital of Indianapolis]] after collapsing during a [[Anthem (company)|WellPoint]] shareholder's meeting in [[Indianapolis]]. Bush was on the company's board of directors. One of the doctors at the hospital said that Bush was alert and talking and he "felt like he was going to be OK".{{cite news|last=Lee|first=Daniel|title=Bush uncle collapses at WellPoint event|url=http://www.indy.com/posts/bush-relative-collapses-during-wellpoint-meeting|access-date=May 18, 2010|newspaper=[[The Indianapolis Star]]|date=May 18, 2010}}{{cite news|last=Barras|first=David|title=Former President Bush's brother collapses at Wellpoint meeting|url=http://www.wishtv.com/dpp/news/local/marion_county/bushs-brother-collapses-at-indianapolis-meeting|access-date=June 28, 2010|newspaper=[[WISH-TV]]|date=May 18, 2010}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{Bush family}} {{Whitney family of Connecticut}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Bush, William H.T.}} [[Category:1938 births]] [[Category:2018 deaths]] [[Category:American bankers]] [[Category:American political fundraisers]] [[Category:Bush family]] [[Category:Businesspeople from Greenwich, Connecticut]] [[Category:Businesspeople from St. Louis]] [[Category:Private equity and venture capital investors]] [[Category:Hotchkiss School alumni]] [[Category:Yale University alumni]] [[Category:Missouri Botanical Garden people]] [[Category:People from Missouri]] [[Category:People from St. Louis]] [[Category:Missouri Republicans]] [[Category:Whitney family of Connecticut]]

'''William Thornton Kemper Sr.''' (November 3, 1866 – January 19, 1938) was the patriarch of the [[Missouri]] Kemper family, which developed both [[Commerce Bancshares]] and [[UMB Financial Corporation|United Missouri Bank]] to become a major banking family in the [[Midwestern United States|Midwest]]. He also founded the Kemper Grain Company and the Kemper Loan and Investment Company. He was treasurer of the Kansas City Commercial Club, a club made of local businessmen to promote [[Kansas City, Missouri|Kansas City]]'s growth.
==Life and career== Kemper was born in [[Gallatin, Missouri]], the son of Sarah Ann (née Paxton) and James Madison Kemper.<ref>http://files.usgwarchives.net/mo/caldwell/misc/booth1a.txt</ref> He swept floors in [[St. Joseph, Missouri]], at the shoe store of his father. One of his accounts was with the [[Valley Falls, Kansas]], firm that his future father-in-law Rufus Henry Crosby owned.{{clarify|What firm was this? The Commerce Bank?|date=April 2018}} He married Charlotte Crosby in 1890 and moved to [[Kansas City, Missouri]], in 1893 where he became president of Commerce Bank in 1903.<ref name=KCPL-WTK-bio>[http://www.kcpl.lib.mo.us/localhistory/media.cfm?mediaID=34915 William T. Kemper biography] - at the Kansas City Public Library</ref>
In 1913 he sold Commerce Bank shares at a price of $220 a share and bought controlling interest in City Center Bank (which was to become UMB Bank). Kemper was to buy back the original Commerce Bank at $86/share.<ref name=KCPL-WTK-bio />
His son James M. Kemper became president of Commerce Bank, while [[R. Crosby Kemper]] became president of City Center.
Kemper’s good fortune was not confined to banking. After being appointed receiver for the bankrupt assets of the [[Kansas City, Mexico & Orient Railroad]], Kemper was awarded 15,000 shares for his duties. Oil was discovered along the railroad's right-of-way. Kemper would make the biggest portion of his fortune by selling these assets to the [[Atchison, Topeka and Santa Fe Railway]], and converting his shares into Santa Fe stock.<ref name=KCPL-WTK-bio /><ref>Garwood, Darrell (1948). ''Crossroads of America: The Story of Kansas City''. W W Norton & Co. p.142, 144-145.</ref>
Kemper's history was intertwined with that of [[Harry S. Truman]]. Truman's father, John Anderson Truman, traded grain commodities futures alongside Kemper until John Truman lost his fortune. John took Harry, then a teenager, to the local [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic]] functions in Kansas City where Kemper was also in attendance. Kemper arranged for Truman to be a page at the [[1900 Democratic National Convention]] in Kansas City. As a young man Harry would go to work in the National Bank of Commerce, 1903–1905, where Kemper was a director. In 1934 during Truman's first run for the [[United States Senate]], Kemper bought the assets of the failed Continental National Bank which included the mortgage on Truman's failed [[haberdashery]] and in turn allowed Truman to retire it for $1,000 (while at the same time also contributing $1,000 to Truman's campaign).<ref>Ferrell, Robert Hugh (1996). ''Harry S. Truman: A Life''. Columbia, Missouri: University of Missouri Press. p. 87. {{ISBN|0-8262-1050-3}}</ref><ref>[[McCullough, David]] (1992). ''[[Truman (book)|Truman]]''. New York: Simon and Schuster, p.63-64, 68. {{ISBN|0-671-86920-5}}</ref>
His former residence was at 1007 Westover Road in Kansas City.
He is the great-great-grandfather of actress [[Ellie Kemper]] and writer [[Carrie Kemper]].
